The young Temüjin began his military training and quickly learned how to lead men, earning his first victories over rival tribes in the region. After gaining experience and expanding his influence, he changed his name to Genghis Khan, meaning "universal ruler," in 1206 after a series of victories that allowed him to consolidate his power over the Mongol tribes.

Genghis Khan's strategic brilliance, adaptability, and merciless determination led him to create one of the largest empires in history, stretching from Eastern Europe to Asia. His success stemmed from his ability to incorporate various conquered peoples, adapting their technologies and tactics to his needs. He also established a strict military code called the "Yassa," ensuring discipline, loyalty, and meritocracy among his warriors.

Some notable achievements of Genghis Khan include the unification of the Mongolian tribes, the conquest of the Jin dynasty in Northern China, and the invasions of Persia, Central Asia, and Eastern Europe. His reign witnessed a significant advancement in communication, trade, and culture. The Mongol Empire brought diverse cultures and technologies together through the establishment of the Pax Mongolica, a period of relative peace and stability across Eurasia.

However, Genghis Khan's rise to power came at a great cost. His conquests resulted in widespread death and destruction, estimated to be in the millions, as he razed cities and enslaved or massacred entire populations.
